Title: Incidence and Risk Factors of Intraoperative Hypotension in Non-Cardiac Surgery: A Retrospective Study

Background: Intraoperative hypotension (IOH) is a critical concern during general anesthesia, yet its incidence in the Japanese population is not well-documented.

Methods: This single-center retrospective study analyzed 11,210 cases out of 13,226 adult patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery at a university hospital between January 2018 and November 2019. IOH was defined as at least one fall of mean arterial pressure (MAP) during general anesthesia, categorized into mild (65 to <75 mmHg), moderate (55 to <65 mmHg), severe (45 to <55 mmHg), and very severe (<45 mmHg). Logistic regression analysis was used to identify factors affecting IOH.

Results: Moderate to very severe hypotension occurred in 86.3% of patients for at least 1 to 5 minutes, with 48.5% experiencing severe or very severe hypotension. Significant risk factors for IOH included female gender, vascular surgery, ASA-PS 4 or 5 in emergency surgery, and the combination with epidural block (EDB). The relative risks for IOH in females compared to males were 1.64 for <75 mmHg, 1.50 for <70 mmHg, 1.40 for <65 mmHg, and 1.36 for <60 mmHg. Vascular surgery was a significant factor for hypotension <55 mmHg.

Interpretation: IOH during general anesthesia is frequent in the Japanese population. Female gender, vascular surgery, ASA-PS 4 or 5 in emergency surgery, and the combination with EDB are independent risk factors associated with IOH. The study did not elucidate the association with patient outcomes.

Trial registration: Not applicable.

Funding: Not specified.
